title: Materials Index
description: Index of available optical material data for Meep simulations

status.description: Current availability of material data files
status.note: Comprehensive material library for plasmonics, photonics, and metasurfaces. Data sourced from refractiveindex.info which compiles standard references (Palik, Rakic, Malitson, Johnson & Christy, Aspnes).

materials.name: Silver (Johnson & Christy)
materials.source: P.B. Johnson and R.W. Christy, Phys. Rev. B 6, 4370-4379, 1972
materials.notes: Lowest optical losses among noble metals. Excellent for high-Q plasmonic resonances. Tarnishes in air.

materials.name: Gold (Palik)
materials.source: Palik, Handbook of Optical Constants of Solids, 1998
materials.notes: Chemically stable, biocompatible. Strong interband transitions below 500nm. Best for resonances >500nm.

materials.name: Copper (Johnson & Christy)
materials.source: P.B. Johnson and R.W. Christy, Phys. Rev. B 6, 4370-4379, 1972
materials.notes: Cheaper than Au/Ag with good plasmonic properties above 600nm. Interband transitions ~590nm cause reddish color. Oxidizes in air.

materials.name: Aluminum (Rakic)
materials.source: Rakic et al., Applied Optics 37, 5271-5283, 1998
materials.notes: Preferred for UV plasmonics due to high plasma frequency. Native oxide layer (Al2O3, ~2-3nm) may shift resonances.

materials.name: Chromium (Johnson & Christy)
materials.source: P.B. Johnson and R.W. Christy, Phys. Rev. B 9, 5056-5070, 1974
materials.notes: Common adhesion layer (2-5nm) between substrates and Au/Ag films. High optical losses. Very hard metal.

materials.name: Titanium (Johnson & Christy)
materials.source: P.B. Johnson and R.W. Christy, Phys. Rev. B 9, 5056-5070, 1974
materials.notes: Used as adhesion layer for Al films. Forms native TiO2 oxide. High losses, not for plasmonics.

materials.name: Nickel (Johnson & Christy)
materials.source: P.B. Johnson and R.W. Christy, Phys. Rev. B 9, 5056-5070, 1974
materials.notes: Ferromagnetic metal for magneto-optical applications. Higher losses than noble metals but enables magnetic control.

materials.name: Platinum (Rakic)
materials.source: Rakic et al., Applied Optics 37, 5271-5283, 1998
materials.notes: Noble metal with excellent chemical stability and catalytic activity. Does not oxidize. Higher losses than Au/Ag.

materials.name: Silicon (Palik)
materials.source: Palik, Handbook of Optical Constants of Solids, 1998
materials.notes: High-index semiconductor (n~3.5 in NIR). Strong absorption above bandgap (~1100nm). Below ~400nm, absorption very strong.

materials.name: Germanium (Aspnes)
materials.source: D.E. Aspnes and A.A. Studna, Phys. Rev. B 27, 985-1009, 1983
materials.notes: Very high index semiconductor (n~4-5). Indirect bandgap 0.66eV (~1880nm), direct gap 0.8eV (~1550nm). Strong absorption in visible.

materials.name: Gallium Arsenide (Aspnes)
materials.source: D.E. Aspnes and A.A. Studna, Phys. Rev. B 27, 985-1009, 1983
materials.notes: Direct bandgap III-V semiconductor (Eg=1.42eV, ~870nm). High index (n~3.5). Absorbs strongly above bandgap.

materials.name: Silicon Dioxide (SiO2, Fused Silica)
materials.source: Malitson, J. Opt. Soc. Am. 55, 1205-1209, 1965
materials.notes: Fused silica (amorphous SiO2). Transparent (k≈0). n varies ~1.55 at 200nm to ~1.44 at 2000nm. Standard substrate.

materials.name: Titanium Dioxide (TiO2, Rutile)
materials.source: J.R. Devore, J. Opt. Soc. Am. 41, 416-419, 1951
materials.notes: High-index dielectric (n~2.4-2.9). Rutile phase, ordinary ray. Transparent in visible. Anatase has slightly different properties.

materials.name: Silicon Nitride (Si3N4)
materials.source: H.R. Philipp, J. Electrochem. Soc. 120, 295-300, 1973
materials.notes: Low-loss dielectric (n~2.0). Standard for photonic waveguides. LPCVD vs PECVD films may differ due to H content.

materials.name: Aluminum Oxide (Al2O3, Sapphire)
materials.source: I.H. Malitson, J. Opt. Soc. Am. 52, 1377-1379, 1962
materials.notes: Crystalline sapphire (alpha-Al2O3), ordinary ray. Native oxide on Al (~2-3nm). Very hard, chemically resistant.

materials.name: Indium Tin Oxide (ITO)
materials.source: T.A.F. König et al., ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 6, 6503-6510, 2014
materials.notes: Transparent conducting oxide (TCO). Properties depend on deposition and doping. Plasmonic behavior in NIR due to free carriers.

materials.name: Graphene (Kuzmenko)
materials.source: A.B. Kuzmenko et al., Phys. Rev. Lett. 100, 117401, 2008
materials.notes: EFFECTIVE optical constants assuming 0.34nm thickness. 2D material - better described by sheet conductivity. ~2.3% absorption per layer.

materials.name: Glass (BK7-like, constant n)
materials.source: Approximate constant index
materials.notes: Constant n=1.51 approximation for generic glass substrate. For accurate results, use malitson_sio2 instead.

materials.name: Air (vacuum approximation)
materials.source: Standard approximation
materials.notes: n=1.0 everywhere. Use for air or vacuum surrounding medium.

materials.name: Water (constant n)
materials.source: Approximate constant index
materials.notes: Constant n=1.33 approximation for water in visible range. Has absorption in IR.

usage.description: How agents should use this material database
usage.lookup_by_id: Load materials/index.json, find material by material_id
usage.tabulated_data: If csv_available is true, load the CSV for tabulated n,k values
usage.meep_model: Use drude_lorentz_fit parameters to construct mp.Medium with E_susceptibilities
usage.validation: Compare computed ε(λ) from fit to tabulated data in Stage 0 (Material Validation)
usage.preference: Prefer tabulated data (csv_available=true) over constant approximations for accuracy

adding_materials.description: How to add new materials to this database
steps: 1. Find tabulated n,k data from refractiveindex.info or literature
2. Create CSV file with columns: wavelength_nm, n, k
3. Include header comments with source citation
5. Add entry to index.json following material_schema.json
6. Set csv_available: true if CSV provided
data_sources: Palik, Handbook of Optical Constants of Solids (1998)
Rakic et al., Applied Optics 37, 5271 (1998) - Metal optical constants
